entry.title: Combined summary - OP_VAULT: a new vault proposal
entry.summary: A proposal for a new Bitcoin vault construction called OP_VAULT has been discussed on the bitcoin-dev mailing list. The proposed design aims to deliver the safety benefits of vaults to users without getting hung up on trying to solve the general problem of covenants. The conversation covered various aspects of the design, including the size and complexity of the witness script, the use of recovery-path construction, and the potential for batching inputs and outputs with compatible vault parameters.James O'Beirne has written a paper summarizing his findings and the resulting proposal, along with an accompanying draft implementation. He may work on a BIP if there is interest. Some concerns were raised about the proposal, such as its potential to encourage address reuse for vaults. Suggestions were made to ensure unique addresses through key derivation and limit the usage of OP_VAULT and OP_UNVAULT to tapscripts only.The conversation revolves around the implementation of efficient wallet vaults, with various proposals and ideas being discussed. One proposal aims to allow a single vault scriptPubKey to receive multiple deposits, but concerns are raised about address reuse. Suggestions are made for batched recovery using separate secrets for each recovery path or having the unvault path for OP_VAULT require the vout number for its corresponding OP_UNVAULT output on the stack.James O'Beirne proposed a new design for vaults, called OP_VAULT, which aims to provide the safety benefits of vaults to users without getting hung up on trying to solve the general problem of covenants. The proposal requires a single additional witness data item during OP_VAULT spend (for unvault path) and transaction introspection checks that the witness item and corresponding output script template match the expected. However, currently there is no way to make this compatible with scripthashes of any kind. In addition, an email thread between James O'Beirne and Andrew regarding a proposed vault design called OP_VAULT has been shared, which aims to deliver the safety benefits of vaults to users without getting hung up on trying to solve the general problem of covenants. The author has implemented three changes based on suggestions from Greg Sanders and AJ Towns, which have improved the proposal. The discussion also touched on issues related to privacy, batched recovery, and the verification process of a node for the destination of a spend using an OP_VAULT output and its corresponding OP_UNVAULT script. The implementation is referenced in the last section of the paper with a link to Github. James O'Beirne's proposal for OP_VAULT aims to deliver the safety benefits of vaults to users without getting hung up on trying to solve the general problem of covenants. While there are still some questions and concerns about implementation and compatibility, a full implementation of the proposal is needed to assess its viability.The email conversation between James O'Beirne and Rijndael discusses the OP_VAULT proposal, and Rijndael finds it cool and thinks it would be an incredibly useful tool for inheritance designs in wallets. The recovery path does not have any real encumbrances on it, and if recovery is triggered, you probably want it for all your inflight unvaultings. A full implementation of the proposal would be valuable to assess its viability.Overall, the proposed design aims to deliver the safety benefits of vaults to users without getting hung up on trying to solve the general problem of covenants, and it may serve as a standard benchmark against which other proposals might be judged.
